description: From Middle English delf, delve, dælf (“a quarry, clay pit, hole; an artificial watercourse, a canal, a ditch, a trench; a grave; a pitfall”), from Old English delf, ġedelf (“delving, digging”) and dælf (“that which is dug, delf, ditch”), from Proto-West Germanic *delban (“to dig”), from Proto-Germanic *delbaną (“to dig”). More at delve.

entries.meaning: A mine, quarry, pit dug; ditch.
(heraldry) A charge representing a square sod.
Alternative form of delft (“style of earthenware”)
examples: Five nothings in five plates of delf
